title: Pittodrie Stadium
text:
Pittodrie Stadium, commonly referred to as Pittodrie, is an <a href="all-seater%20stadium">all-seater stadium</a> in <a href="Aberdeen">Aberdeen</a>, Scotland. Used primarily for <a href="Association%20football">football</a>, it has been the home ground of the <a href="Scottish%20Professional%20Football%20League">Scottish Professional Football League</a> (SPFL) club <a href="Aberdeen%20F.C.">Aberdeen F.C.</a> since they were formed in 1903. Prior to then, the ground hosted the <a href="Aberdeen%20F.C.%20%281881%29">original Aberdeen F.C.</a> from 1899 until the merger that created the present club.
With a <a href="seating%20capacity">seating capacity</a> of ; Pittodrie is the <a href="List%20of%20football%20stadiums%20in%20Scotland">fourth largest stadium in the SPFL</a> and the largest stadium in Scotland outside the <a href="Central%20Belt">Central Belt</a>. Pittodrie has been the location of a number of firsts in the field of stadium design, including the invention of the <a href="Dugout%20%28football%29">dugout</a>, and in 1978 became one of the first all-seater stadia in the United Kingdom.
, Pittodrie has hosted fifteen matches involving the <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland national team</a>. The ground has also staged <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>, with four <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland international</a> fixtures being held there including a match against the Barbarians. In club football, <a href="Inverness%20Caledonian%20Thistle%20F.C.">Inverness Caledonian Thistle</a> temporarily shared Pittodrie during part of the 2004–05 season.
History.
The <a href="Aberdeen%20F.C.%20%281881%29">original Aberdeen football club</a> was formed in 1881. They played at various venues within the city, until a former dung hill for police horses was cleared and readied for football in 1899. The land was leased from Mr Knight Erskine of Pittodrie, with an agreement to construct a terrace on what is now the site of the Richard Donald Stand. The first game, a 7–1 win over <a href="Dumbarton%20F.C.">Dumbarton</a>, was played on 2 September 1899. The club was merged on 18 April 1903 with two other local clubs, <a href="Victoria%20United%20F.C.">Victoria United</a> and <a href="Orion%20F.C.">Orion</a>, to form <a href="Aberdeen%20F.C.">Aberdeen FC</a>. 8000 spectators turned up to watch the new Aberdeen FC play its first game at Pittodrie, a 1–1 draw in the Northern League against <a href="Stenhousemuir%20F.C.">Stenhousemuir</a> on 15 August 1903. The club joined the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League">Scottish Football League</a> in 1904.
Increasing popularity of the team and rising attendances led to major developments at Pittodrie in the 1920s. The club purchased the ground, which they had been leasing, with the final payment made on 1 December 1920. The Main Stand, where the club offices, dressing rooms and trophy room are located, was constructed in 1925. This was partly funded by the sale of <a href="Alex%20Jackson%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201905%29">Alex Jackson</a> to <a href="Huddersfield%20Town%20F.C.">Huddersfield Town</a>. Also in the 1920s, the <a href="Dugout%20%28football%29">dugout</a> was introduced to football by Aberdeen coach <a href="Donald%20Colman">Donald Colman</a>, who was interested in sitting lower to the pitch in order to inspect the players' footwork.
The club won its first major trophy in 1947, when it won the <a href="Scottish%20Cup">Scottish Cup</a>. With increased success came more additions to Pittodrie. The record attendance occurred on 13 March 1954, when 45,061 spectators turned up for a Scottish Cup match against <a href="Heart%20of%20Midlothian%20F.C.">Hearts</a>. <a href="Floodlights%20%28sport%29">Floodlights</a> were introduced at Pittodrie on 21 October 1959, when <a href="Football%20in%20England">English</a> <a href="Football%20League">league</a> side <a href="Luton%20Town%20F.C.">Luton Town</a> were beaten 3–2 in a friendly. By 1 August 1968, the Main Stand had become all-seated as part of a £100,000 improvement of the ground. This coincided with a change of name from Pittodrie Park to Pittodrie Stadium. On 6 February 1971, a fire destroyed part of the Main Stand, and gutted the dressing rooms and club offices. The Scottish Cup trophy, which was held by Aberdeen at the time, had to be rescued by firemen.
In 1978, Pittodrie became the second <a href="All-seater%20stadium">all-seated stadium</a> in Great Britain, after the south terracing was fitted with bench style seating. (<a href="Clydebank%20F.C.%20%281965%29">Clydebank</a> had done something similar two years before as a response to being promoted to the Premier Division). This improvement pre-dated the <a href="Taylor%20Report">Taylor Report</a> on British football grounds by a decade and coincided with a distinct upturn in the fortunes of the home team, now managed by <a href="Alex%20Ferguson">Alex Ferguson</a>. The south side became the South Stand in 1980, following the installation of a <a href="cantilever">cantilever</a> roof which covered most of the seats. A year later, the benches were replaced by individual seats.
Both during the subsequent run in the 1980s and at numerous other times over the century the stadium has been in operation, there have been many memorable nights for the local fans. However, Pittodrie's greatest night is generally regarded as 16 March 1983. Aberdeen fought back from 2–1 down in a <a href="UEFA%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">European Cup Winners' Cup</a> quarter-final second leg tie against <a href="FC%20Bayern%20Munich">Bayern Munich</a> to win 3–2. A full house witnessed this victory, which took the Dons through to the semi-finals, and they went on to win the trophy by defeating <a href="Real%20Madrid%20CF">Real Madrid</a> in the <a href="1983%20European%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup%20Final">final</a>. The club installed 24 executive boxes in the Main Stand, and built a new roof over the Merkland Road End in 1985. Undersoil heating was installed in 1987.
The most recent development of the stadium came in the <a href="1992%E2%80%9393%20in%20Scottish%20football">1992–93 season</a> when the Beach End stand on the east side of the ground was demolished, with the new <a href="Dick%20Donald">Richard Donald</a> stand - named after the club's long serving chairman - constructed in its place. On 1 August 1993, the new stand was opened with a <a href="Scottish%20League%20Cup">League Cup</a> tie against <a href="Clydebank">Clydebank</a>. The official opening was carried out later in 1993 by <a href="Anne%2C%20Princess%20Royal">Princess Anne</a>. It is currently the only two tier stand in the stadium. The stadium has remained relatively unchanged since then, although some minor improvements, such as the introduction of an electronic stadium entry system for the <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20in%20Scottish%20football">2006–07 season</a>, have been carried out.
The site of the stadium is only 550 yards away from the <a href="North%20Sea">North Sea</a>, and with only the King's Links golf course between the stadium and the beach, the ground is one of the coldest football grounds in Britain.
As a result of a <a href="Groundshare">ground sharing</a> agreement, Pittodrie was used by <a href="Inverness%20Caledonian%20Thistle%20F.C.">Inverness Caledonian Thistle</a> for their home matches during the early part of the <a href="2004%E2%80%9305%20in%20Scottish%20football">2004–05 season</a>. This was required because Inverness CT's own <a href="Caledonian%20Stadium">Caledonian Stadium</a> did not meet the requirements for entry into the <a href="Scottish%20Premier%20League">Scottish Premier League</a> until improvements were carried out and the <a href="seating%20capacity">seating capacity</a> increased. In 2005 the stadium size criterion for entry to the SPL was reduced to 6,000, thereby allowing Inverness Caledonian Thistle to return to their home stadium partway during the season.
In March 2020 the club announced plans to reduce the operational capacity of Pittodrie to 15,500.
Structure and facilities.
The Main Stand was the original <a href="grandstand">grandstand</a> within the ground, and contains much of the staff and offices responsible for the day-to-day running of the stadium, from the boot room to the trophy room. Teams enter the pitch from a tunnel to the extreme left of this stand. As befits a main stand, this section of the ground includes both padded seating for club officials and <a href="Very%20Important%20Person">VIPs</a>, and several <a href="executive%20boxes">executive boxes</a> at the rear. There are a number of pillars running along this stand, supporting the roof. As a consequence, views in some places are restricted. It remains, however, the most expensive stand from which to watch matches. To the east of the Main Stand is the club shop, which doubles as a ticket office.
The Richard Donald Stand is named after former club chairman <a href="Dick%20Donald">Dick Donald</a>. Completed in 1993, it houses over 6,000 fans, although this is a reduction on its Beach End predecessor. It is a <a href="cantilever">cantilever</a> construction with two tiers and a row of twelve executive boxes in between. It is commonly referred to as simply the "RDS". It was built by the present chairman's construction firm, the Stewart Milne Group, at a cost of £4.5 million. Within this stand are a number of banqueting rooms, which are used for corporate hospitality and outside bookings.
Taking its name from the street behind it, the Merkland Stand (also known as 'the Paddock' or 'King Street End') sits behind the goal, on the west of the ground. The Merkland is Aberdeen F.C.'s family stand, with reduced prices for under-twelves and families. There is also a section for disabled supporters near the pitch. The stand itself is a covered enclosure, with two pillars supporting the roof. The entrance to the stand is dominated by a <a href="fa%C3%A7ade">façade</a> constructed from <a href="granite">granite</a>, a local stone.
Named simply after its position within the ground, the South Stand was originally an undeveloped embankment which was later remodelled as a standing terrace. Seating and a cantilever roof were later added, although some of the 8,400 seats remain uncovered. Since 1993, the easternmost part of the stand has been used to house away fans. Sections P, Q and R are designated for this purpose. The <a href="television">television</a> gantry and <a href="Play-by-play">commentary</a> positions are housed in this stand.
Future developments.
Despite improvements and its ground-breaking past, it appears that the future of Pittodrie as a football stadium is uncertain. Plans are in action for the club to move to a <a href="New%20Aberdeen%20Stadium">New Aberdeen Stadium</a>. The principle of a move, rather than a redevelopment of Pittodrie, has already been recommended by <a href="Aberdeen%20City%20Council">Aberdeen City Council</a>. An earlier plan to move to the edge of the city, which corresponded with Scotland's failed joint bid for the <a href="Euro%202008">Euro 2008</a> tournament, was scrapped.
In June 2006, the club's two major shareholders agreed a plan to sell the land on which the stadium sits to clear some of the club's debt.
During the late 2010s, construction began at Kingsford on the western edge of the city which led to the completion of a new training facility, <a href="Cormack%20Park">Cormack Park</a>, in 2019; however, the proposed stadium on the same site was put on hiatus due to economic issues, and in 2021 alternative designs at the <a href="Aberdeen%20Beach%20and%20Queens%20Links">city's beachfront</a> close to Pittodrie were released.
Other uses.
Since its construction, there have been fifteen <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a> international matches staged at Pittodrie. Normally the national team's home matches are played at <a href="Hampden%20Park">Hampden Park</a> in <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, but during times of redevelopment of the national stadium, or matches which are expected to draw a low crowd, the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20Association">Scottish Football Association</a> has made use of other stadia in the country. Playing at Pittodrie, Scotland have won ten matches, drawn two and lost three. The most recent was a 1–0 loss to <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">Netherlands</a> on 9 November 2017.
Rugby union.
Since 2005, Pittodrie has hosted four <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> internationals.
Concerts.
Pittodrie has been used for concerts; both <a href="Elton%20John">Elton John</a> and <a href="Rod%20Stewart">Rod Stewart</a> have played at Pittodrie.
